thread.title: With extra day of rest before Game 2, Jake Arrieta should be strong - Chicago Tribune
thread.title_full: With extra day of rest before Game 2, Jake Arrieta should be strong - Chicago Tribune

author: Mark Gonzales
title: With extra day of rest before Game 2, Jake Arrieta should be strong - Chicago Tribune
text:
Joe Maddon is coping with a head cold, but the Cubs manager will trust his eyes Sunday night when evaluating workhorse Jake Arrieta during Game 2 of the National League Championship Series.
"He'll have an extra day (of rest)," Maddon said of Arrieta, who has thrown a career-high 243 2/3 innings but had his streak of scoreless innings stop at 34 after allowing four runs in only 5 2/3 Monday against the Cardinals. "My plan is to watch. I don't go with any preconceived thoughts and will react accordingly."
Arrieta, a 22-game winner in the regular season who was 17-1 during a 21-game stretch before Monday's game, wasn't as sharp and "that may speak to a little bit of fatigue, possibly," Maddon said. "I'm not sure."
Arrieta, however, said he felt strong after throwing a bullpen session Thursday.
"Obviously, there are certain things you can't control," Arrieta said before Saturday's Game 1. "But physically, my body feels great. There's some still some work for me to be done, and I don't think I've gotten to the end of my leash yet."
Maddon said he was more willing to let Arrieta pitch a 113-pitch complete game against the Pirates in the NL wild-card game on Oct. 7 "just because of the magnitude of the situation."
Arrieta was 2-0 this year with a 1.13 ERA in two starts against a Mets lineup that has been upgraded significantly since.

Berry added: Outfielder Quintin Berry was added to the 25-man NLCS roster in place of shortstop Addison Russell, who will miss the series with a moderate strain of his left hamstring.
Berry has stolen 27 bases in 28 attempts in his major-league career. Maddon thinks there could be more pinch-running opportunities in the series and that's why he didn't add an infielder to replace Russell.
Left-handed hitting outfielder Chris Coghlan also can play the infield.
The Cubs elected to keep their 11-man pitching staff intact. The biggest test could occur in Game 4 if the Cubs empty their bullpen for Game 3.
Maddon hasn't decided who will start Games 3 and 4, but Kyle Hendricks and Jason Hammel are the primarily candidates.
Rested relievers: Maddon was delighted Jon Lester and Arrieta were starting the first two games, with the expectation that their endurance will allow the bullpen to get more rest.
"I was concerned earlier," said Maddon, noting that Pedro Strop appeared in 76 games and closer Hector Rondon 72 — each career highs.
"We were able to back off. They caught their breath, and they're looking pretty good right now."
